title: Kleiner Perkins on TechCrunch Live: Avoiding Burnout with Mamoon Hamid and Arianna Huffington

rawLines.text: Hey everyone, I'm Matt Burns and this is
Techrunch Live where we help founders
build better ventureback businesses.
Welcome to the show and it's been a
serious wild ride the last seven days.
There's so much to talk about SVB
collapse check GPT released the 4.0
version and there's so much more. And
did you see that new BlackBerry video or
trailer? It looks good. Well, it looks
really good to be honest. You should
watch that. Anyway, we have two
fantastic guests today for TechCrunch
Live. Both are longtime veterans to
Silicon Valley and American Business.
And these episodes are scheduled out
months in advance, but these two
particular guests are perfect to talk
through what's happening right now.
First, we have Moon Hemmed. He's a
partner at Kleiner Perkins for nearly
six years, and before that, he was
general partner at Social Capital, which
he founded with Chimoth. So, yeah,
Mammoon knows Silicon Valley and can
help explain what comes next. And then
there's uh Ariana Huffington, the
co-founder of uh Huffington Post and a
roundabout way, my former boss back when
AOL owned Techrunch and the Huffington
Post and there was just so much drama.
But in 2016, she left the Huffington
Post and then the very next month
founded Thrive Global. So far, she's
raised 170 million for Thrive in the
goal of improving company or wellness of
company employees. But I'm not
interviewing them as much as I would
like to. Alex Wilhelm is best suited for
this interview. So, we brought him on
board to do this. Alex is the
editor-inchief of TechCrunch Plus,
TechCrunch's subscription service. He's
great and you're going to love him. And
he's going to talk to Mimoon and Ariana
for 25 minutes. Then it's your turn.
You're going to have 10 minutes to ask
questions through the Hopin platform. If
you're not in Hopin, you should have a
link on YouTube and Twitter spaces right
now. So, uh, with that, I think we can
jump right in the interview. One more
thing, after the interview, we have
pitch practice. So stay through to the
interview for that. So that's enough
from me. Uh Alex, let's shoot it over to
you. It's all all you now. All right.
All right. Well, hello everybody. Uh I
did not uh I did not think we were going
to have so much news right before we had
this conversation. In fact, we had a
prep call the other week and it was all
focused on mental health and employee
care and the corporate buying
environment and then everything kind of
went boom. So, uh just because we can't
not tip our hat at the news, I'm going
to have a couple quick questions about
SVB. Then we're going to dive into the
other stuff. But just to start, uh,
Mammoon, how are your port codes doing?
How's Kleiner doing? Is your money safe?
So, what a week, Alex. Like, I think
since the last time we spoke, uh, I
think I came out of COVID quarantine and
then here we are. SVB happened. But, uh,
it's been, uh, what a week, what a ride
it's been. But, uh, just to answer your
question, uh, everyone's fine. Every
company's doing just fine. every company
was able to make payroll on Monday,
Tuesday, Wednesday when it mattered. Uh
we over the weekend scrambled to set up
lines of credit to support our portfolio
companies in the case they needed
capital uh to their bank accounts to
make payroll as did many other venture
capital firms. So um you know
fortunately uh none of those companies
actually needed the capital from us but
we were ready uh and everyone's fine.
everyone actually is number one priority
was payroll that's done now it's like
day two day three stuff which is you
know what do you do next and I think
there's um some stabilization that's
happened over the past even 24 hours and
uh we feel really good about where we
are but I think there's some just
thoughts around where to go next in

a startup and what do you do what are
some procedures and uh you'll see a lot
of that over the coming weeks and months
for startups just to manage cash, which
was something that wasn't really talked
about uh prior to this. Yeah, I I I
think we're having conversations that we
never really had before, like how many

silly question two months ago, but now
here we are. And then Ariana, you know,
one thing I've been thinking about on
these second order effects for founders
isn't just can can Thrive make payroll.
It sounds like you can, but I'm very

when we closed our series C that Mammoon
Kleiner led, we put all $80 million that

it uh only because we got a better rate
on the
money hi- which was great and we had
just left the the foundation money.
Thrive has a foundation and we had left

those deposits are safe as we
know. But what was

H what was so interesting is how
differently founders address the

talking making
decisions but in terms of how much

as people were on Twitter.

at the core of it you know our personal

I think that's where really thrive fits

stress burnout like and I go back to

So, um, your company has integrated into
a lot of kind of workplace, uh,
environments where people can do kind of

very
integrated h so in fact everything we

Salesforce Levis we also offer for free

and again there is data here that shows

But anyway, be that as it may, you are

So we want to make sure that you have

h but the stresses at home which

I I want to go back to to the product

And I I I find it um a little bit ironic

uh participate in a challenge, whatever

reset
directly. And I love the 60-second

unavoidable. There is no job that is

stress free. Cumulative stress is a
avoidable and we now know from

to course correct from stress to move

I are any of those people who love it
end users? Um, they are because you know
the those who care a lot about
